column2: Russian pronunciation: [ʐʊˈkofskʲɪj]) is a city in Moscow Oblast
column5: 40 kilometers (25 mi) southeast of Moscow. Population: 104

column1: The urban-type settlement of Stakhanovo was founded in 1935 from the dacha settlement Otdykh (literally
column2: "Relaxation"). It was named after Alexey Stakhanov
column3: a famous Soviet miner. On April 23
column5: the settlement was granted town status and renamed Zhukovsky
column6: in honor of the pioneer of aero- and hydrodynamics Nikolay Zhukovsky.

column1: Within the framework of administrative divisions
column2: it is incorporated as Zhukovsky City Under Oblast Jurisdiction—an administrative unit with the status equal to that of the districts. As a municipal division
column3: Zhukovsky City Under Oblast Jurisdiction is incorporated as Zhukovsky Urban Okrug.

column1: Zhukovsky is a home to the M. M. Gromov Flight Research Institute and N. Ye. Zhukovsky Central Aerohydrodynamic Institute — they are two major facilities involved in testing and designing aircraft. These facilities were employers for a great portion of the city's population before perestroika. Also
column2: there is situated the Aeromechanics faculty of MIPT.

column1: Tikhomirov Scientific Research Institute of Instrument Design (НИИП

column2: EMZ).The airline Aviastar-TU has its head office in Zhukovsky.There are also a number of flight testing divisions of the aviation design bureaus (Sukhoy
column5: etc.) located in the area as well as machine-building plants

column2: President Vladimir Putin signed a presidential decree establishing the National Aircraft Industry Centre.

column1: Zhukovsky is the center of track and field athletics in Moscow Oblast. Most notable athletes born in Zhukovsky are Yuriy Borzakovskiy
column5: and others. In 2005 the Meteor international standard athletics stadium was opened.

column1: There was also a bandy club Strela based in Zhukovsky.
